bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to John B. Moore, September 22, 1898
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: INDEX BUREAU REC'D NOV 8 '98 DEPT OF STATE

p.add: 2D ASSISTANT SECRETARY, Aus. no probability of a war vessel visiting Monrovia in the near future and if it did, no accommodation for passage. NOV 8 1898

div1.p: No. 5, Consular Series, Consulate General of the U. States, Monrovia Liberia Sept 22, 1898
Owen L. W. Smith, to Hon. John B. Moore, Asstistant Secretary of State, Wasington.
Subject: The Indigent Todd children; late of Minneappolis, Minnesota
No. 5, Consular Series Consulate Gen'l of the U. States, Monrovia, Liberia; Sept. 22, 1898.
Hon. J. B. Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, Wasington.

Sir: I have the honor, to say that in my dispatch No 4, Consulor Series, Sept 19, 1898, I endeavored to setforth the deplorable condition and suffering of the late J. C. Todd's children, late of Minneapolis; now in Liberia.
I appealed to the Department, if possible, for permission to send the said 4 children, back to America. See this, I desire to say that while writing my dispatch

dispatch. No. 28, Diplomatic Series, Sept. 22, 1898, it suggested itself to me, that should the Department see fit to send a Cruiser out here in December, next, with the expectation of returning, direct to America, that by order of the Department, that would be the cheapest and most direct way of having said children returned to America.
